title: Woman removes nail varnish using Vaseline, lemon juice and TOOTHPASTE
title_page: Woman removes nail varnish using Vaseline, lemon juice and TOOTHPASTE | Daily Mail Online
text:
A woman has revealed an ingenious beauty hack that shows how to remove nail varnish using a blob of toothpaste, Vaseline and lemon juice.
Glittery nail varnish is notoriously difficult to take off but Prachi Agarwal, an Indian beauty blogger, appears to have come up with a foolproof method for removing it and has shared it in a YouTube video.
Using toothpaste and a nail brush, she scrubs off the paint in less than two minutes as it peels off in large, easy chunks.
Using a minimal amount of nail varnish removal fluid - which can contain high amounts of acetone - she simply squeezes a blob of normal toothpaste onto a plate.
She then mixes it with water using a cotton bud, then applies the mixture to the nails with a plastic nail brush.
Prachi uses nail varnish remover and wipes to erode the top layer, adding that Vaselines and lemon juice are optional.
Prachi has devised a method of getting rid of nail varnish using toothpaste, lemon juice and Vaseline
After mixing the ingredients together on a small plate, she applies the mix to a nail brush and begins scrubbing
The nail varnish begins to come away in less than two minutes as toothpaste contains ethyl acetate
She also stresses that the trick works best for powder glitter-based varnishes.
She begins by removing the top coat with regular nail varnish remover and a cotton wool pad, then applies Vaseline to the nails.
Water and toothpaste are then added to the mix - with an optional squirt of lemon juice for whitening - as the mixture is rubbed onto the nails vigorously using a nail brush.
It comes off in large chunks (left) as the toothpaste works its magic, before coming off completely (right)
After just a few seconds, the nail varnish begins to fall off in large chunks. This is because toothpaste contains ethyl acetate, which is also found in nail varnish remover.
Prachi advises washing your hands afterwards and adding Vaseline again to moisturise the nails and cuticles.
The video has racked up almost half a million views.
